This module allows you to change structural information of SIS. Do not introduce changes unless strictly advised. Press Confirm if you wish to continue or press Cancel to return to the main menu.
You are about to save your changes. This will affect the structure of the database. Press Cancel if you are not sure, otherwise press Confirm to save changes.

There are four pages in the Finance module: Balance, Activity, Deposits and Expenditure. Swipe your finger across the screen to switch from one page to another.

Shows information for:

Previous Balance: is the balance for the previous month.
Deposits: is the total amount of grants received in the current month.
Expenditures: is the total amount of expenses in the current month.
Available balance: is the total deposits minus total expenditures.

Shows deposits and expenditures for a period of time:

INITIAL DATE: select the initial date for the activity.
FINAL DATE: select the final date for the activity.
Current balance: is the total deposits minus total expenditures.
Date: is the date of the deposit or expenditure.
Descriptions: is the description of the deposit or expenditure.
Deposits: is the amount of the deposit.
Expenditures: is the amount of the expenditure.

Allows you to register the grants that are received:

DATE: select the date in which the grant was received.
Deposit Type: select from the drop down list.
Amount: is the total amount of the grant received.
Observation: is description of the grant received.
Once all fields are complete press
Once all fields are complete press

Allows you to register all the expenses that have been incurred:

DATE select the date in which the expense was incurred.
Expenditure Type select from the drop down list.
Amount is the total amount of the expense incurred.
Observation is description of the expense incurred
To add teachers or non-teaching staff press + symbol below
To assign subject to the teacher press + symbol on the upper right hand corner
To add student press + symbol below. Update yearly or when necessary.

The Student report card replicates the information regarding each Student that has been entered during Student registration. The Grade and Stream can be selected, and consequently the Student from each class. It contains information regarding historical enrollment, Attendance, Evaluation and Behavior.

The attendance report by Student requires the selection of the grade, stream and month. As this is selected the list of Students with percentage of attendance is displayed. This percentage is obtained by dividing the number of days attended by the days in the time period.

This report presents the attendance average. Once the grade and stream are selected, three charts are presented. The first chart shows a tendency line of the primary attendance average of the entire school. The second chart shows the yearly attendance of the selected grade. The last graph shows the average attendance, as historical trend of months of the selected stream.

Student-Classroom Ratio aims to show the concentration of Student per classroom. It is calculated by dividing the number of Students by the number of classrooms. This is an important issue since it is a good measure of how close to the standard the school is. The indicator is illustrated using a line graph with three color sections. The yellow section, indicating a class with too few Students. The green section indicates the ideal number of students per classroom, while the red one shows there is overcrowding in the school.
This summary shows the total amount of students, and the totals per gender, as well as the total number of teachers by gender.
This report allows the user to schools the grade, stream, subject and specific exam. Once the user has selected these parameters, a list of students with their individual scores appears.

This report allows the user to schools the grade, stream, and subject. Once the user has selected these parameters, two tendency line graphs appear. The first graph shows the average in the selected subject for the entire Standard. The second graph shows the historical average for the subject in the selected Stream.

The General Deposit Report shows the sum of the deposits made for each months up to date. If a month does not appear it means that no data was recorded for the month. It also presents the sum of all deposits made and recorded for the current year. The graph below shows the monthly deposits with a tendency line.
This report shows a chart of how financial resources are being used by adding all expenditures per type. It adds a bar graph with the total amount of resources used per expenditure.

Primary textbooks by grade and subject allows the user to select the subject he or she wants to view. The chart shown below expresses the number of textbook per subject selected, the number of students per standard and the student-to-textbook ratio in the last column.

This reports shows the total number of students per disability, per stadard, in the school. The intention of this report is allow the teacher to prepare the necessary services and resources a student with a particular disability requires.
This report summarizes the number of repeaters by standard and the total number of students enrolled for the current year.

The staff attendance report requires the selection of the month. As this is selected the list of teachers with percentage of attendance is displayed. This percentage is obtained by dividing the number of days attended by the days in the time period.
If a staff is absent remember to check a reason for absence before saving.
If a student is absent remember to check a reason for absence before saving.
9. How many students are enrolled in this school?
3.a. Does the school have a source of drinking water?
3.c. What is the secondary source of drinking water (mark all that apply)?

This report presents staff attendance for an entire month, day by day. It marks with a dot the days that the teacher is present, and an \"A\" for absent. Blank spaces are days where attendance was no taken. The information presented is for the current year.

This report presents Student attendance for an entire month, day by day. It marks with a dot the days that the teacher is present, and an \"A\" for absent. This attendance report requires the selection of the grade, stream and month. This report presents information for the current year.

This indicator shows the average number of students assigned to each teacher per level (primary and pre-primary). The graph shows a line with the average number of students per teacher for the entire school. The yellow section, indicating a class with too few Students. The green section indicates the ideal number of students per classroom, while the red one shows there is overcrowding in the school. It is important to observe that if a teacher is assigned to two grades, it is counted in both.

The student-textbook ratio shows the ratio of children who share one textbook. It is calculated by dividing the number of children in the particular standard by the amount of textbooks by subject. The first number in the ratio is the number of children who share the book, the second number is alway one, indicating the one book they share. This is illustrated using a gauge that starts at 0 and goes up to 5, 0 to 2 is marked green indicating there is less than two children sharing one book. Then from 2 to 3 it is market in orange, which means 2 to 3 children are sharing one book. Beyond 3 it is colored in red, which means that more than 3 children are sharing one book.

The Distribution of Resources by source report intends to show what source of funds the school relies on the most. It shows two graphs; the first is a pie graph that shows of the percentage of each source of funds. The second is a bar graph comparing the total amount of funds by source.

The Primary Student- Pit Latrine Ratio report shows the total number of pit latrines and the facilities available for girls and boys, and the enrollment. It also shows the ratio which is calculated by dividing the total number of students by the amount of pit latrines. It establishes a range of what is an acceptable amount of latrines, a regular and insufficient pit latrines for the amount of students.
Please wait for the report to finish.
